item.title: Halcyon Happenings: Newsletter 159
item.description:
We hope you are having a great half-term break!
Halcyon’s Halloween Catwalk
On Monday 31 October there will be a Halloween Catwalk at lunchtime (1230) in the Stern Hall. Students and staff can come to school in a Halloween costume (please ensure that your costume is appropriate and will not offend anyone).

If you would like to wear a costume, please bring £1 to school as a donation to the CRIS Cancer foundation.

There will be:
  • sweet treats for 50p
  • games
  • a spooky catwalk
Two students and two teachers will act as a panel to judge the catwalk participant’s costumes. The winning costumes might even win some prizes!

If you have any questions please email Anthony Gow or speak to Elisabet, Martina, Sabrina or Siri in Grade 9. 

See a selection of photos from last year’s catwalk here!
Engineering Education Scheme - Parents Needed
Grade 11 Physics have been accepted into the EES (Engineering Education Scheme). This is a unique and exciting opportunity for Halcyon’s keen engineers. The EES organisation will find a company to work with 4-6 students. Students will meet company engineer representatives  at their headquarters or a nearby university for an introductory workshop. The students will then be assigned an engineering project by the company to complete over the next six months. Upon  completion, students will present to senior engineers and if the project passes evaluation it will be incorporated into company practice.

This is an amazing opportunity, but the number of schools applying outnumber the quantity of companies who know to participate. The organisation has advised that students are permitted to source their own company. 

Grade 11 physics students are looking for a company that would welcome their participation in an engineering project and  is interested in helping educate the next generation of engineers. 

Please email Lori Fritz if you know a company that you think would be suited to this project.
Grade 7 Theatre Trip
Before the end of term, Grade 7 went to the Gielgud Theatre to see the production of The Curious Incident of The Dog in The Night Time. In their English lessons, Grade 7 are currently studying the novel upon which the production is based. The trip aimed to help students understand the characters and themes. Following the trip, students were asked to write a review of the performance for a summative assessment. It was a great production enjoyed by students and staff.
Grade 8 Field Trip
Location: Dickens Museum, 48 Doughty St, London WC1N 2LX
Date: Friday 11 November
Time: 1245-1600
Students will have the opportunity to step back in time and walk in the footsteps of Charles Dickens and his former home. The museum houses the world's finest and most comprehensive collection of material relating to Dickens with over 100,000 items including furniture, personal effects, paintings, prints, photographs, letters, manuscripts, and rare editions. 

Students will leave school at 1245 and return by 1600.  

Students should bring: 
  • A topped-up Oyster card
  • Comfortable walking shoes
  • Filled water bottle
  • Charged iPad
If you have any questions regarding this trip, please email Gabriel English.
Mark Your Calendar: Halcyon’s Football Fixtures
  • Monday 07 November, 1615-1700, under 17’s girls football match vs International Community School (Westway)
  • Thursday 10 November, 1615-1700, under 16’s boys football match vs Dwight London International School (Seymour Leisure Centre)
  • Monday 21 November, 1615-1700, under 16’s boys football match vs International Community School (Westway)
Please feel free to come and cheer on our teams! Any questions please email Oisin Byrne.
Extracurricular Activity: Choir Club
We are delighted to announce that West End performer Amanda Posener will be running choir at Halcyon. Amanda has been in many West End shows including The Lion King, Dancing in the Streets and Avenue Q. She is currently performing at The Gielgud Theatre in The Curious Incident of The Dog in The Night Time. The Club will be singing many different styles from pop to musical theatre.

The Club will start on Wednesday 02 November. Price per session for the remainder of this term will be £50 - payment method to be agreed personally with Amanda. Please get in contact with her to express your interest and get more information mandascaramanda@hotmail.com. Furthermore, Amanda will be available for individual lessons on request. Do not hesitate to ask her.
Term 2 Tuition
Parents are gently reminded that Halcyon has sent out notices for Term 2 tuition, which is due by Monday 31 October. Please contact the school (admin@halcyonschool.com) if you have any questions or concerns. Thank you.
HPC Inside Tour of Tate Britain
Date: Wednesday 09 November 
Time: 1030-1230
Cost: £15.00
Meet: at Tate Britain entrance at the Manton entrance, Atterbury Street
''Tate Britain, sited on the old Millbank Penitentiary - a huge prison from where many men were deported to Australia - is now the home of British Art and, from these wonderful works, you can tell the history of this nation through its art. JMW Turner, has a whole wing to himself.'' 

Please sign up for this here. Contact Stacey Ciauri 07557520442 with any questions.
HPC Halcyon Next Social Mixer
Date: Monday 14 November
Time: 1830
Location: Bernardis, Seymour Street
Please save the date! Go downstairs to our private room where there will be a cash bar and tapas.

Hope to see you all there. Any questions please contact Stacey Ciauri on 07557520442.
HPC: Exhibition The Vulgar, Fashion Redefined
Location: Barbican Art Gallery
Date: Wednesday 23 November
Time: 1000-1200
Meeting Point: the Barbican (more details to follow upon confirmation)
Cost: £36 (including exhibition entrance ticket)
This new exhibition conceived by exhibition-maker Judith Clark and psychoanalyst Adam Phillip will look at the notion of vulgarity in fashion inviting the viewer to think again about exactly what makes something vulgar and why it is such a sensitive and contested term. Drawn from major public and private collections worldwide, the show will include contributions from leading modern and contemporary designers such as Walter van Beirendonck, Manolo Blahnik, Christian Dior, Marc Jacobs for Louis Vuitton, Stephen Jones, Christian Lacroix, Karl Lagerfeld for Chloé and Chanel, Alexander McQueen for Givenchy, Prada and Vivienne Westwood.

Please RSVP here and also register here. For any questions contact Stacey Ciauri 07557520442.
Halcyon Parents' Trip to Bicester Shopping Outlets
Date: Thursday 24 November 
Details provided soon. Please save the date. Contact Stacey Ciauri 07557520442 with any questions.

Calendar
Directory
6. Connect With Us
Administrative Officer: Laura Olmedo | 020 7258 1169
Director: Barry Mansfield
IBMYP Coordinator: Lori Fritz
IBDP Coordinator: Pat Kyle
Student Wellbeing Leader: Gareth Jones
Digital Learning Leader: Jon Neale

Upcoming Open House Mornings: Dates Here

item.title: Halcyon Happenings: Newsletter 158
item.description:
Director's Message, Half Term Break
 
Dear Students, Staff and Parents,

I hope that everyone has enjoyed the first half-term of the school year. I say ‘enjoyed’ very deliberately because we know we all learn better when we are enthused and engaged; I know there has been fabulous learning taking place - from our week-long residential trips, through field trips around London during our Community Days, to great IB learning across our classes, and teacher professional learning days. We have all been engaged, given our best and made progress as individuals and as a learning community. We aim for learning to give us a sense of success and help us feel fulfilled.

This year we have established Exploration classes and started a one-to-one mentoring programme for all students. We have also sought to expand the time available for personal and service learning, through our vertical mentor groups. These programmes aim to provide students with an opportunity to shape (some of) their learning. It also allows more time to reflect on their experiences and be supported in making positive changes. By having a greater sense of ownership of their learning, students should find learning more enjoyable and satisfying.

I trust our parents have enjoyed their learning too, coming to our workshops and orientation evenings. I hope that we have communicated our enjoyment of being a part of the Halcyon experience, and presented our school as a place that prizes inquiry, discovery and innovation. I know that our parents are always there to support both the school and their own learning - thank you! 

Finally, and not by any means last, our staff have supported the changes we have made this year and been wonderful ambassadors for innovation. They, too, have taken on new ideas and different ways of learning, and I believe this is one of the many reasons why Halcyon is such a great place to be; as staff members we all enjoy learning together and then sharing that with the students and parents.

Wherever you may be over the coming vacation - enjoy!

Best wishes,
This Week’s Community Day
 
Grade 6
Grade 6 students visited the British Museum and looked at ancient civilisations, focussing on works of art and artefacts. Students gained an understanding and appreciation of the cultures the artwork represented.

They studied the types of symbols used and how these express the identity of their culture. Students discussed how the British Museum housed a wide range of artworks representing different cultures. The group mostly focussed on the Aztec, North American, Inuit, Sri-Lankan and African works of art. Students had the opportunity to make many drawings for inspiration. Their  research  unearthed how the masks were used and how they were made.
Grade 7
While at the Olympic Park, Grade 7 students completed this mathematics worksheet which helped them appreciate the legacy of the Olympic site. For instance, one of the facts they discovered was that East Village of the site was the athletes village during the Olympic and Paralympic Games. Close to 16,000 athletes and team officials resided there during the Olympic Games, and 7,200 during the Paralympic Games.
Grade 8
Grade 8 students visited the Thames Explorer Trust in Chiswick. They collected data on the physical processes and ecology of the River Thames, and learnt about the role of the river in London’s history and the ways London protects itself from flooding.
Grade 9
Grade 9 visited the Royal Courts of Justice, where they took part in a mock murder trial. Luckily, the accused was freed, due to insufficient evidence. After lunch, students had a wonderful tour of the Inns of Court, called "Discovering Legal London". They learned all about the legal system of England and Wales.
Grade 10
Grade 10 students visited the Clink Prison Museum and the Museum of London. They investigated the question "What does the history of crime and punishment tell us about changing views of individual liberty and how society should deal with crime?". This visit supported part of their PSHE unit on liberty, equality and democracy. The day started with a look at modern justice as students participated in a simulated jury trial in the classroom. Then students visited the Clink Prison museum and the Museum of London gathering information for their own documentaries about crime and punishment.
DP Students (Grades 11 & 12)
The field trip to the Tate Modern and Tate Britain (aka "Tate to Tate") was planned for IB Diploma students with a focus on Visual Arts and Theory of Knowledge (ToK). The art works displayed evoked some interesting connections to epistemological categories of understanding and enabled students to engage in a detailed comparative analysis, where students looked for cultural, contextual, formal, and conceptual links. Students also had the opportunity to see iconic British artworks such as the paintings of John Constable and Joseph Turner.
Student Council Elections

“One of the best things about being at Halcyon is being part of the community.” Ellery, Running for President.

On Tuesday Halcyon ran its Student Council elections. The Council provides a platform for students to explore their voice, freedom of speech and opportunity to discover and support new views from the community. Exploring and understanding leadership roles also provides powerful learning.

The candidates presented themselves clearly and enthusiastically to their peers. Evy, Grade 10, running for Secretary, stated:

“I’ve watched the school grow and change and sat back with my thoughts and opinions, but I want to take the initiative now to actively participate.”

Today, the results are in! Halcyon's 2016/17 Student Council is:
  • Treasurer: Kieran, Grade 11
  • Secretary: Evy, Grade 10
  • Vice President: Beckett, Grade 10
  • President: Ellery, Grade 10
Well done to everyone who ran for a position and to those who won the election! Looking forward to a productive year of student governance.
We present Halcyon's 2016/17 Student Council!
2016-2017 Junior Intern Programme, USC Shoah Foundation Institute for Visual History
Congratulations to Evy, Grade 10, who has been chosen to participate in the 2016-2017 Junior Intern Programme for the USC (University of Southern California) Shoah Foundation Institute for Visual History.

Evy was one of only three students selected from outside of southern California and so will meet virtually with the other participants. 

"Through this programme, participants will have the opportunity to work in a university environment while developing an understanding of different types of memory, deepen proficiency in digital literacy and improve communication skills. There will also be community service opportunities and field trips. In addition, participants will contribute to the Institute's development of IWitness educational resources that will be available to teachers and students worldwide. Through these activities, interns will think about what it means to be a responsible participant in civil society as they develop the knowledge, skills and confidence to believe they have a role in creating positive change in their own lives and communities."

What a fantastic opportunity and we wish Evy all the best in her endeavour.
Thanks to great word-of-mouth recommendations from Halcyon families, our Open Houses have been extremely busy. Find our Open House dates here.
HPC Tour of Greenwich
The HPC had a great turnout for their tour of Greenwich on Wednesday 19 October. We heard it was a lot of fun to take the clipper across the Thames to Greenwich where a London historical tour expert, Philippa Owen, showed them all the key sites.
Mark Your Calendar: Halcyon’s Football Fixtures
  • Monday 07 November, 1615-1700, under 17’s girls football match vs International Community School (Westway)
  • Thursday 10 November, 1615-1700, under 16’s boys football match vs Dwight London International School (Seymour Leisure Centre)
  • Monday 21 November, 1615-1700, under 16’s boys football match vs International Community School (Westway)
Please feel free to come and cheer on our teams! Any questions please email Oisin Byrne.
Interview with a Medical Student
This week, Halcyon's Grade 11 and 12 students were visited by a current UK medical student, Biha Malhotra. Biha discussed medical careers and studying medicine in the UK. Halcyon students inquired about the application process, requirements and what life in med school is really like. What a great contact for the students to keep in touch with.
Engineering Education Scheme - Parents Needed
Grade 11 Physics have been accepted into the EES (Engineering Education Scheme). This is a unique and exciting opportunity for Halcyon’s keen engineers. The EES organisation will find a company to work with 4-6 students. Students will meet company engineer representatives  at their headquarters or a nearby university for an introductory workshop. The students will then be assigned an engineering project by the company to complete over the next six months. Once completed, students will present to senior engineers and, if the project passes evaluation it will be incorporated into company practice.

This is an amazing and unique opportunity, but the number of schools applying outnumber the quantity of interested companies. The organisation has advised that students are permitted to source their own company from the school community. 

Grade 11 physics students are looking for a company that either would welcome their participation in an engineering project and  is interested in helping educate the next generation of engineers. 

Please email Lori Fritz if you know a company that you think would be suited to this project.
New Staff Announcement, Deirdre Williams
We are delighted to introduce you to Deirdre Williams, “Dee”, the new Cook, who will be joining Halcyon's catering team. Dee brings a great deal of experience and passion to her work and she is looking forward to collaborating with students, parents and staff to further integrate and develop the food culture at Halcyon including our commitment to our international community, delicious and nutritious cuisine and sustainability. 

Dee believes that the enjoyment of food starts with our eyes and enjoys making dishes that are attractive as well as wonderful on the palate.

Dee feels that there is a wonderful opportunity to grow at Halcyon, and as someone who enjoys learning and making progress, there is already room for improvement and she looking forward to joining a team with those same values.
Find out how much Halcyon raised for its first ever Pink Walk in aid of Breast Cancer!
HPC Inside Tour of Tate Britain
Date: Wednesday 09 November 
Time: 1030-1230
Cost: £15.00
Meet: at Tate Britain entrance at the Manton entrance, Atterbury Street
''Tate Britain, sited on the old Millbank Penitentiary - a huge prison from where many men were deported to Australia - is now the home of British Art and, from these wonderful works, you can tell the history of this nation through its art. JMW Turner, has a whole wing to himself.'' 

Please sign up for this here. Contact Stacey Ciauri 07557520442 with any questions.
HPC Halcyon Next Social Mixer
Date: Monday 14 November
Time: 1830
Location: Bernardis, Seymour Street
Please save the date! Go downstairs to our private room where there will be a cash bar and tapas.

Hope to see you all there. Any questions please contact Stacey Ciauri on 07557520442.
HPC: Exhibition The Vulgar, Fashion Redefined
Location: Barbican Art Gallery
Date: Wednesday 23 November
Time: 1000-1200
Meeting Point: the Barbican (more details to follow upon confirmation)
Cost: £36 (including exhibition entrance ticket)
This new exhibition conceived by exhibition-maker Judith Clark and psychoanalyst Adam Phillip will look at the notion of vulgarity in fashion inviting the viewer to think again about exactly what makes something vulgar and why it is such a sensitive and contested term. Drawn from major public and private collections worldwide, the show will include contributions from leading modern and contemporary designers such as Walter van Beirendonck, Manolo Blahnik, Christian Dior, Marc Jacobs for Louis Vuitton, Stephen Jones, Christian Lacroix, Karl Lagerfeld for Chloé and Chanel, Alexander McQueen for Givenchy, Prada and Vivienne Westwood.

Please RSVP here and also register here. For any questions contact Stacey Ciauri 07557520442.

Date: Thursday 24 November 
Details provided soon. Please save the date. Contact Stacey Ciauri 07557520442 with any questions.

  • Monday 07 November, 1615-1700, under 17’s girls football match vs International Community School (Westway)
  • Thursday 10 November, 1615-1700, under 16’s boys football match vs Dwight London International School (Seymour Leisure Centre)
  • Monday 21 November, 1615-1700, under 16’s boys football match vs International Community School (Westway)
Please feel free to come and cheer on our teams! Any questions please email Oisin Byrne.
Interview with a Medical Student
This week, Halcyon's Grade 11 and 12 students were visited by a current UK medical student, Biha Malhotra. Biha discussed medical careers and studying medicine in the UK. Halcyon students inquired about the application process, requirements and what life in med school is really like. What a great contact for the students to keep in touch with.
Engineering Education Scheme - Parents Needed
Grade 11 Physics have been accepted into the EES (Engineering Education Scheme). This is a unique and exciting opportunity for Halcyon’s keen engineers. The EES organisation will find a company to work with 4-6 students. Students will meet company engineer representatives  at their headquarters or a nearby university for an introductory workshop. The students will then be assigned an engineering project by the company to complete over the next six months. Once completed, students will present to senior engineers and, if the project passes evaluation it will be incorporated into company practice.

This is an amazing and unique opportunity, but the number of schools applying outnumber the quantity of interested companies. The organisation has advised that students are permitted to source their own company from the school community. 

Grade 11 physics students are looking for a company that either would welcome their participation in an engineering project and  is interested in helping educate the next generation of engineers. 

Please email Lori Fritz if you know a company that you think would be suited to this project.
New Staff Announcement, Deirdre Williams
We are delighted to introduce you to Deirdre Williams, “Dee”, the new Cook, who will be joining Halcyon's catering team. Dee brings a great deal of experience and passion to her work and she is looking forward to collaborating with students, parents and staff to further integrate and develop the food culture at Halcyon including our commitment to our international community, delicious and nutritious cuisine and sustainability. 

Dee believes that the enjoyment of food starts with our eyes and enjoys making dishes that are attractive as well as wonderful on the palate.

Dee feels that there is a wonderful opportunity to grow at Halcyon, and as someone who enjoys learning and making progress, there is already room for improvement and she looking forward to joining a team with those same values.
Find out how much Halcyon raised for its first ever Pink Walk in aid of Breast Cancer!
HPC Inside Tour of Tate Britain
Date: Wednesday 09 November 
Time: 1030-1230
Cost: £15.00
Meet: at Tate Britain entrance at the Manton entrance, Atterbury Street
''Tate Britain, sited on the old Millbank Penitentiary - a huge prison from where many men were deported to Australia - is now the home of British Art and, from these wonderful works, you can tell the history of this nation through its art. JMW Turner, has a whole wing to himself.'' 

Please sign up for this here. Contact Stacey Ciauri 07557520442 with any questions.
HPC Halcyon Next Social Mixer
Date: Monday 14 November
Time: 1830
Location: Bernardis, Seymour Street
Please save the date! Go downstairs to our private room where there will be a cash bar and tapas.

Hope to see you all there. Any questions please contact Stacey Ciauri on 07557520442.
HPC: Exhibition The Vulgar, Fashion Redefined
Location: Barbican Art Gallery
Date: Wednesday 23 November
Time: 1000-1200
Meeting Point: the Barbican (more details to follow upon confirmation)
Cost: £36 (including exhibition entrance ticket)
This new exhibition conceived by exhibition-maker Judith Clark and psychoanalyst Adam Phillip will look at the notion of vulgarity in fashion inviting the viewer to think again about exactly what makes something vulgar and why it is such a sensitive and contested term. Drawn from major public and private collections worldwide, the show will include contributions from leading modern and contemporary designers such as Walter van Beirendonck, Manolo Blahnik, Christian Dior, Marc Jacobs for Louis Vuitton, Stephen Jones, Christian Lacroix, Karl Lagerfeld for Chloé and Chanel, Alexander McQueen for Givenchy, Prada and Vivienne Westwood.

Please RSVP here and also register here. For any questions contact Stacey Ciauri 07557520442.
Halcyon Parents' Trip to Bicester Shopping Outlets
Date: Thursday 24 November 
Details provided soon. Please save the date. Contact Stacey Ciauri 07557520442 with any questions.
App Directory
Calendar
Directory

item.title: Halcyon Happenings: University and Careers Offerings
item.description:
University and Careers Offerings

While half term is right around the corner, the University and Careers programme has quite a few events planned this week! If you have any questions regarding the content below, please email Mark Bowen.
University Visits
We are pleased to host two separate events involving three different universities.

On Wednesday 19 October at 1600, we will host the KIC Assist Mini College Fair which will offer information on the American college application process with representatives from the University of Houston and Florida International University who will also present on their own institutions. Please note this event is open to the whole community so Halcyon parents are also welcome. The fair will take place in the Hub at Halcyon London International School. If you are a parent and would like to attend please RSVP here.

On Thursday 20 October at 1300, Halcyon will host New York University (NYU) in a workshop for Grade 11 and 12 students in the Hub. The NYU representative will share information on the original New York campus, as well as Shanghai and Abu Dhabi.
 
Careers Information
A current UK medical student, Biha Malhotra, will be offering a session to interested Grade 11 and 12 Halcyon students on Friday 21 October at 1315 in the Hub. Biha will discuss medical careers and studying medicine in the UK. A big thanks to Kerry Jenkins for her assistance in facilitating this visit.
PSAT
The PSAT will be offered to all Grade 11 students on Wednesday 19 October beginning at 0900 and lasting until 1145.

item.title: Halcyon Happenings: Newsletter 157
item.description:
View this email in your browser

Community Day - Monday 17 October

Halcyon students will be out and about around London for most of Monday 17 October on a variety of exciting excursions. The day will start at school, so please arrive as normal at 0900. Students will be released from school as normal - at 1600 - unless otherwise noted. After school activities will take place as usual.

Grade 6 British Museum
Grade 6 are visiting the British Museum to explore the use of masks used by different cultures.  This will give the students an opportunity to look at the way the various cultures have used materials, textures and patterns to express and transform the performer.  Students are working with masks both in drama and art and will be able to continue their research, making connections for their ideas to enable them to begin constructing their plaster masks over the coming weeks.

Students need to bring:

  • a fully topped up Oyster card
  • a fully charged iPad
  • money for lunch or a packed lunch
  • comfortable shoes and a jacket
  • a full water bottle
Students should meet in the art room (2.10) 9.00 am Monday. Please contact Sue Dance if you have any questions.

Grade 7 Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park Trip
During this trip to the Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park, students will develop a sense of the lasting legacy that the 2012 Olympic games has left on the world, and compare it with that of other games. Students will acquire an appreciation and respect for various cultures through skills developed in PE (orienteering) and mathematics (measuring). Students will also learn about the health benefits of parks and open places for local communities.

Students should take:

  • a charged iPad
  • a charged phone
  • a topped up Oyster card
  • rain gear in case it rains
  • money for lunch or a packed lunch
  • filled water bottle
If you have any questions, please contact Dinis Costa

Grade 8 Thames Explorer Trust
Grade 8 will be visiting Thames Explorer Trust in Chiswick for their river study investigation. As discussed in class students will need to bring:

  • a packed lunch and drinking water
  • appropriate clothing for the weather – come dressed for rain and shine!
  • Wellingtons, boots or spare shoes - the foreshore will be very muddy and students will get dirty
  • a plastic bag to take the muddy footwear home
  • a spare pair of socks
  • a topped up Oyster Card
If you have any questions, please contact Jon Simpson.

Grade 9 Royal Courts of Justice
Grade 9 will be visiting the Royal Courts of Justice (RCJ) to take part in a mock trial, for which they have been preparing in their PSHEE lessons. In the afternoon, they will be taking part in a walking tour, "Discovering Legal London". As discussed in class students will need to bring:

  • a packed lunch or money to buy lunch, and a bottle of drinking water
  • comfortable walking shoes
  • appropriate clothing for the RCJ (smart casual) and the weather on the walk – come dressed for rain and shine
  • pen in preparation for their mock trial
  • a topped up Oyster Card
Students will return to Halcyon at 16.15.

Grade 10 Museum of London and Clink Prison Museum
Grade 10 students will investigate the question : "What does the history of crime and punishment tell us about changing views of individual liberty and how society deals with crime?" in visits to the Museum of London and the Clink Prison Museum. They will produce a short documentary on the subject and share it in their PSHE lessons where they are presently debating issues relating to freedom and responsibility of the individual in society.

  • a charged iPad
  • a charged phone
  • a topped up Oyster card
  • rain gear in case it rains
  • money for lunch or a packed lunch
  • filled water bottle
Please contact Lori Fritz with any questions.

Grades 11 / 12 Tate Modern and Tate Britain
This is a combined ToK and Visual Arts trip. We shall be exploring British art at its best. We start by spending the morning at the Tate Modern, where students will have time to visit several exhibitions. After lunch we shall travel by ferry to the Tate Britain. There will be a particular focus on embracing tradition and experimentation in equal measure.

 Students will need to bring:
  • a charged iPad
  • a charged phone  
  • a topped up Oyster card
  • rain gear in case it rains
  • money for lunch or a packed lunch
  • filled water bottle

Please contact Oisin Byrne with any questions.

IB Curriculum Workshop - Understanding Assessment at Halcyon
Date: Tuesday 18 October
Time: 1830-2000
Location: Halcyon London International School

Find out more about the philosophy and practice of assessment in the IB programmes: How are criteria used to help students know how to improve? How are semester grades arrived at?  What is the role of external assessment in the programmes? Please feel free to bring your questions to the session. We would like to encourage parents to attend who would like to improve their knowledge on IB Assessment. Please RSVP here.

If you have any questions, please email Lori Fritz for IBMYP or Pat Kyle for IBDP.

Grade 7 Theatre Trip
Date: Thursday 20 October
Time: 1300-1750
Location: Gielgud Theatre
Grade 7 will be visiting the Gielgud Theatre in the West End to see a performance of The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time. As discussed in class, students will need to bring:

  • comfortable walking shoes
  • appropriate clothing for the theatre (smart casual) and the weather on the walk – come dressed for rain and shine!
  • a pen and paper incase they wish to take notes
Students will return to Halcyon at 17.50 (unless they have made arrangements to be picked up at the theatre). Please contact Ross McGowan if you have questions.

Vision / Mission Workshop 

Date: Tuesday 08 November 1830 - 1930

Location: Halcyon London International School

You will have received an email from Achim Beck, School Board Chair regarding this workshop. As a part of our strategic plan, we are committed to reviewing Halcyon’s vision, mission and core objectives. To facilitate this process, we would like to invite you into school to join a discussion asking what it means to have a Halcyon education. Our school’s purpose (what we intend to achieve) should be expressed in our vision and mission and we feel that the current version should be reviewed with the goal of ensuring it expresses our central values succinctly and with great clarity.

The forum is open to all members of our community and the evening will be conducted following a workshop format. We will work in small groups, with some guiding questions, to consider the essential purpose of our school and how best we can put that into words. The discussions and ideas will be collected and taken forward by a working committee, who will report a final recommendation to the Board. The Board has also heard recommendations and ideas from an external consultant who supported the school during our strategic planning last year.

If you are interested in joining our discussion, do please RSVP here. If you have any questions, please email Achim Beck.
Mark Your Calendar: 3 Way Conferences
Date: Monday 14 November AND Thursday 17 November
Time: 1600-1900
Location: Halcyon London International School
Please mark your calendar for our upcoming innovative 3 way conference (student, parent, teachers):
  • Monday 14 November is for families with surnames A - K
  • Thursday 17 November is for families with surnames L - Z
We will send out a link shortly for the booking system.
 
The sessions are designed to give all of our parents the opportunity to speak with their child(ren)’s teachers about interim semester reports. Please note that students are expected to attend so they can be a part of any reflection about how to improve their learning. The discussion should be as student-led as possible, so we encourage students to discuss their successes and targets for improvement and to outline what they feel they have achieved over the first quarter of the school year. Students and parents are encouraged to read through reports together and consider any questions they might have about the student progress. Reports will be issued immediately prior to the first conference day.
App Directory
Calendar
Directory



Grade 12 Biology - Internal Investigations
This week Grade 12 IB Diploma biology students began to examine their Internal investigation task. For any piece of scientific work students will be doing intensive research to back up their hypothesis with evidence. Students have already shown great personal engagement and started their exploration before they move on to the analysis, evaluation and communication tasks of their investigation. This investigation is led by Mr Jones and supervised and assisted by Mr Hagos.



Spanish debate about "Columbus Day"
On Thursday, our Spanish students held a debate examining several celebrations that occur on 12 October in different countries around the world.  The discussion focused on the controversy around the festivity celebrated in the USA as Columbus Day, in Spain as 'Día de la Hispanidad' and National Day and in most of the countries in Latin America  as 'Día de la Raza' , 'Día de la resistencia indígena', or 'Día de la Hispanidad'. On the one hand this festivity represents the idea of the union of different cultures under the identity of the same language; on the other hand, it is contended that this date coincides with the genocide of indigenous populations such the Inca, Aztec or Maya.

Participants:

  • Presentaton: Maria Berni
  • Moderator: Evy Stumpff
  • Judges: Kieran, Nate, Alexi
  • Table 1: Eric, Eliot, Alexia, Javier
  • Table 2: Scott, Gabriel, Christina, Manuel
  • Simultaneous translation: Gwen, Daphni, Melina
¡Enhorabuena a todos los participantes por su intervención!
 

Halcyon students attend LSE lecture on the Bangladeshi Liberation War
On Thursday 13 October, some Grade 10 students and a parent accompanied Ms Cooke and Ms Gonzalez to a talk by Dr Nayanika Mookherjee on the legacy of rape during the Bangladeshi Liberation War of 1971. Other academics in related fields contributed to the discussion. Themes discussed included the narrative of the Birangona - the labelling of the victims of rape as 'war heroines'; how the events changed relations between men and women in Bangladesh and the role of ethnicity, religion and gender in the conflict and its aftermath.  Furthermore, the difficulties of hearing from the multitude of different voices with different experiences and balancing that with prosecutions and the slow pace of the justice system. Students are currently starting to prepare for a conference on sexual violence in conflict using different languages of expression and this talk certainly gave them an important insight into the challenges facing justice and legacy in the aftermath of war crimes.



Mark Levy, life-long Civil Rights activist, speaks at Halcyon today
Many students as well as some staff and a parent enjoyed hearing Facing History and Ourselves speaker, Mark Levy, an American life-long Civil Rights activist speak about his life and specifically his experiences as part of the Civil Rights Movement during the late 1950’s and 1960’s. Mark was part of the Freedom Schools which were connected to the Freedom Riders Movement. Spending the summer with his wife in the home of a black family in Mississippi was a life-threatening situation for all of them due to the intense racism of the time and the local, active Ku Klux Klan. The Freedom Schools were formed by trained volunteers who spent time training the next generation of activists in the South of the US in any facility made available to them, from front porches and fields to derelict seminaries. The curriculum Mark and others were trained to deliver focused on helping young blacks examine and clarify what this integrated world they were working toward would look like. What did white society have that they would like to have? What did black culture have that they wanted to see in this new world? What things did neither have that they could work toward together? A thoughtful and unifying approach in very tough times. Students were able to make connections to some of today’s issues both locally and internationally with regard to identity, belonging and oppressive behaviours.

Halcyon Football Match

Congratulations to the boys football team who won 5-0 vs International Community School this week. Kieran scored the first goal, Matis and Jeremy each scored a brace, and Ale defended well. Well done to the squad for their effort and sportsmanship!

Tuition Invoices for Term 2
Tuition invoices for Term 2 have been sent this week and are due 01 November. If you have not received an invoice from payment@halcyonschool.com please check your spam folder and remember to add the address to your contacts list. If you have any questions, please email: payment@halcyonschool.com and we will reply shortly.

Volunteer sought to assist with Halcyon Swim Club
We have had wonderful uptake for our after school swim club. So we are seeking a female parent to support Gareth Jones in overseeing the Swim Club every Friday from 1600 - 1715 to assist with escorting to the Seymour Leisure Centre and while female students use the changing rooms. The volunteer needs to either have a DBS check or be willing to go through this process. Please contact Gareth Jones if you can help.
Our Open Houses are filling up fast! If you would like to reserve a place for someone please do so here.
HPC: Drop-in Meetings
NEW Date: Thursday 20 October
Time: 0900
Location:  The Borough Barista, 60 Seymour St, W1H 7JN
Each month the HPC meets at a local cafe to discuss all things HPC related as well as touch upon a variety of topics of interest:  NHS v Private Medical, Holiday Ideas, etc. Please think about popping by to say "hi" as well as to meet and connect with other Halcyon parents.
HPC: Inside Tour of Tate Britain
Date: Wednesday 09 November 
Time: 1030-1230
Meet: at Tate Britain entrance at the Manton entrance, Atterbury Street
''Tate Britain, sited on the old Millbank Penitentiary - a huge prison from where many men were deported to Australia - is now the home of British Art and, from these wonderful works, you can tell the history of this nation through its art. JMW Turner, has a whole wing to himself.'' 

Please sign up for this here. Contact Stacey Ciauri 07557520442 with any questions.
HPC: Take a Historical Tour Around Greenwich
Date: Wednesday 19 October
Time: 1000-1230
Cost: £15.00 per person to be paid on day of tour

Meet: at the Thames Clipper ticket booth opposite Embankment Tube Station at 1000 for a 1012 Clipper boat departure to Greenwich

Return: at the end of tour on the DLR
Halcyon parents are invited to come check out Greenwich with a professional elite tour guide and UK Historian Philippa Owen (she makes every tour worthwhile and fascinating).

Philippa says: "Greenwich, the gateway to London! A beautiful oasis on the mighty bend of the river, this World Heritage site looks over at Canary Wharf where once ships not banks traded their wares. Always a royal place, Henry the VIII and his two daughters were born there. The Queen's House and Mary II began the story of the Royal Naval College.Time is measured from there and its story is linked to the history of exploration and empire. A fascinating place, we will arrive by boat along the Royal River as so many have done before."

Please sign up here. Contact Stacey Ciauri 07557520442 with any questions.
HPC: Exhibition The Vulgar, Fashion Redefined
Location: Barbican Art Gallery
Date: Wednesday 23 November
Time: 1000-1200

Meeting Point: the Barbican (more details to follow upon confirmation)
 
Cost: £36 (including exhibition entrance ticket)
This new exhibition conceived by exhibition-maker Judith Clark and psychoanalyst Adam Phillip will look at the notion of vulgarity in fashion inviting the viewer to think again about exactly what makes something vulgar and why it is such a sensitive and contested term. Drawn from major public and private collections worldwide, the show will include contributions from leading modern and contemporary designers such as Walter van Beirendonck, Manolo Blahnik, Christian Dior, Marc Jacobs for Louis Vuitton, Stephen Jones, Christian Lacroix, Karl Lagerfeld for Chloé and Chanel, Alexander McQueen for Givenchy, Prada and Vivienne Westwood.

Please RSVP here. For any questions contact Stacey Ciauri 07557520442.
Connect With Us
Administrative Officer: Laura Olmedo | 020 7258 1169
Director: Barry Mansfield
IBMYP Coordinator: Lori Fritz
IBDP Coordinator: Pat Kyle
Student Wellbeing Leader: Gareth Jones
Digital Learning Leader: Jon Neale

Upcoming Open House Mornings: Dates Here

We will send out a link shortly for the booking system.
 
The sessions are designed to give all of our parents the opportunity to speak with their child(ren)’s teachers about interim semester reports. Please note that students are expected to attend so they can be a part of any reflection about how to improve their learning. The discussion should be as student-led as possible, so we encourage students to discuss their successes and targets for improvement and to outline what they feel they have achieved over the first quarter of the school year. Students and parents are encouraged to read through reports together and consider any questions they might have about the student progress. Reports will be issued immediately prior to the first conference day.
App Directory
Calendar
Directory



Grade 12 Biology - Internal Investigations
This week Grade 12 IB Diploma biology students began to examine their Internal investigation task. For any piece of scientific work students will be doing intensive research to back up their hypothesis with evidence. Students have already shown great personal engagement and started their exploration before they move on to the analysis, evaluation and communication tasks of their investigation. This investigation is led by Mr Jones and supervised and assisted by Mr Hagos.



Spanish debate about "Columbus Day"
On Thursday, our Spanish students held a debate examining several celebrations that occur on 12 October in different countries around the world.  The discussion focused on the controversy around the festivity celebrated in the USA as Columbus Day, in Spain as 'Día de la Hispanidad' and National Day and in most of the countries in Latin America  as 'Día de la Raza' , 'Día de la resistencia indígena', or 'Día de la Hispanidad'. On the one hand this festivity represents the idea of the union of different cultures under the identity of the same language; on the other hand, it is contended that this date coincides with the genocide of indigenous populations such the Inca, Aztec or Maya.

Participants:

  • Presentaton: Maria Berni
  • Moderator: Evy Stumpff
  • Judges: Kieran, Nate, Alexi
  • Table 1: Eric, Eliot, Alexia, Javier
  • Table 2: Scott, Gabriel, Christina, Manuel
  • Simultaneous translation: Gwen, Daphni, Melina
¡Enhorabuena a todos los participantes por su intervención!
 

Halcyon students attend LSE lecture on the Bangladeshi Liberation War
On Thursday 13 October, some Grade 10 students and a parent accompanied Ms Cooke and Ms Gonzalez to a talk by Dr Nayanika Mookherjee on the legacy of rape during the Bangladeshi Liberation War of 1971. Other academics in related fields contributed to the discussion. Themes discussed included the narrative of the Birangona - the labelling of the victims of rape as 'war heroines'; how the events changed relations between men and women in Bangladesh and the role of ethnicity, religion and gender in the conflict and its aftermath.  Furthermore, the difficulties of hearing from the multitude of different voices with different experiences and balancing that with prosecutions and the slow pace of the justice system. Students are currently starting to prepare for a conference on sexual violence in conflict using different languages of expression and this talk certainly gave them an important insight into the challenges facing justice and legacy in the aftermath of war crimes.



Mark Levy, life-long Civil Rights activist, speaks at Halcyon today
Many students as well as some staff and a parent enjoyed hearing Facing History and Ourselves speaker, Mark Levy, an American life-long Civil Rights activist speak about his life and specifically his experiences as part of the Civil Rights Movement during the late 1950’s and 1960’s. Mark was part of the Freedom Schools which were connected to the Freedom Riders Movement. Spending the summer with his wife in the home of a black family in Mississippi was a life-threatening situation for all of them due to the intense racism of the time and the local, active Ku Klux Klan. The Freedom Schools were formed by trained volunteers who spent time training the next generation of activists in the South of the US in any facility made available to them, from front porches and fields to derelict seminaries. The curriculum Mark and others were trained to deliver focused on helping young blacks examine and clarify what this integrated world they were working toward would look like. What did white society have that they would like to have? What did black culture have that they wanted to see in this new world? What things did neither have that they could work toward together? A thoughtful and unifying approach in very tough times. Students were able to make connections to some of today’s issues both locally and internationally with regard to identity, belonging and oppressive behaviours.

Halcyon Football Match

Congratulations to the boys football team who won 5-0 vs International Community School this week. Kieran scored the first goal, Matis and Jeremy each scored a brace, and Ale defended well. Well done to the squad for their effort and sportsmanship!

Tuition Invoices for Term 2
Tuition invoices for Term 2 have been sent this week and are due 01 November. If you have not received an invoice from payment@halcyonschool.com please check your spam folder and remember to add the address to your contacts list. If you have any questions, please email: payment@halcyonschool.com and we will reply shortly.

Volunteer sought to assist with Halcyon Swim Club
We have had wonderful uptake for our after school swim club. So we are seeking a female parent to support Gareth Jones in overseeing the Swim Club every Friday from 1600 - 1715 to assist with escorting to the Seymour Leisure Centre and while female students use the changing rooms. The volunteer needs to either have a DBS check or be willing to go through this process. Please contact Gareth Jones if you can help.
Our Open Houses are filling up fast! If you would like to reserve a place for someone please do so here.
HPC: Drop-in Meetings
NEW Date: Thursday 20 October
Time: 0900
Location:  The Borough Barista, 60 Seymour St, W1H 7JN
Each month the HPC meets at a local cafe to discuss all things HPC related as well as touch upon a variety of topics of interest:  NHS v Private Medical, Holiday Ideas, etc. Please think about popping by to say "hi" as well as to meet and connect with other Halcyon parents.
HPC: Inside Tour of Tate Britain
Date: Wednesday 09 November 
Time: 1030-1230
Meet: at Tate Britain entrance at the Manton entrance, Atterbury Street
''Tate Britain, sited on the old Millbank Penitentiary - a huge prison from where many men were deported to Australia - is now the home of British Art and, from these wonderful works, you can tell the history of this nation through its art. JMW Turner, has a whole wing to himself.'' 

Please sign up for this here. Contact Stacey Ciauri 07557520442 with any questions.
HPC: Take a Historical Tour Around Greenwich
Date: Wednesday 19 October
Time: 1000-1230
Cost: £15.00 per person to be paid on day of tour

Meet: at the Thames Clipper ticket booth opposite Embankment Tube Station at 1000 for a 1012 Clipper boat departure to Greenwich

Return: at the end of tour on the DLR
Halcyon parents are invited to come check out Greenwich with a professional elite tour guide and UK Historian Philippa Owen (she makes every tour worthwhile and fascinating).

Philippa says: "Greenwich, the gateway to London! A beautiful oasis on the mighty bend of the river, this World Heritage site looks over at Canary Wharf where once ships not banks traded their wares. Always a royal place, Henry the VIII and his two daughters were born there. The Queen's House and Mary II began the story of the Royal Naval College.Time is measured from there and its story is linked to the history of exploration and empire. A fascinating place, we will arrive by boat along the Royal River as so many have done before."

Please sign up here. Contact Stacey Ciauri 07557520442 with any questions.
HPC: Exhibition The Vulgar, Fashion Redefined
Location: Barbican Art Gallery
Date: Wednesday 23 November
Time: 1000-1200

Meeting Point: the Barbican (more details to follow upon confirmation)
 
Cost: £36 (including exhibition entrance ticket)
This new exhibition conceived by exhibition-maker Judith Clark and psychoanalyst Adam Phillip will look at the notion of vulgarity in fashion inviting the viewer to think again about exactly what makes something vulgar and why it is such a sensitive and contested term. Drawn from major public and private collections worldwide, the show will include contributions from leading modern and contemporary designers such as Walter van Beirendonck, Manolo Blahnik, Christian Dior, Marc Jacobs for Louis Vuitton, Stephen Jones, Christian Lacroix, Karl Lagerfeld for Chloé and Chanel, Alexander McQueen for Givenchy, Prada and Vivienne Westwood.

Please RSVP here. For any questions contact Stacey Ciauri 07557520442.
Connect With Us
Administrative Officer: Laura Olmedo | 020 7258 1169
Director: Barry Mansfield
IBMYP Coordinator: Lori Fritz
IBDP Coordinator: Pat Kyle
Student Wellbeing Leader: Gareth Jones
Digital Learning Leader: Jon Neale

Location: Halcyon London International School

  • Thursday 17 November is for families with surnames L - Z
We will send out a link shortly for the booking system.

The sessions are designed to give all of our parents the opportunity to speak with their child(ren)’s teachers about interim semester reports. Please note that students are expected to attend so they can be a part of any reflection about how to improve their learning. The discussion should be as student-led as possible, so we encourage students to discuss their successes and targets for improvement and to outline what they feel they have achieved over the first quarter of the school year. Students and parents are encouraged to read through reports together and consider any questions they might have about the student progress. Reports will be issued on Friday 11 November.
Community Day, Tuesday 04 October
Students and teachers shared some fantastic photos from their community days this week! Please have a look below.
Grade 6 studied urban ecosystems at Hyde Park.
Grade 7 students experienced a cultural exchange for one day discussing art, customs and history of Spanish speaking countries and sharing a tapas lunch with their Spanish peers while at a Spanish secondary school based in London.
Grade 8 discovered a range of interactive exhibitions at the Science Museum.
Grade 9 explored East London on a street art tour finding out how artists have expressed their social views.
Grade 10 observed and discussed figurative work at the Tate Britain.
Grade 11 learned about the workings of the Royal Courts of Justice and took part in a mock trial.
Halcyon’s Lockdown Procedure
We will shortly be trialing our first lockdown drill. This is a routine procedure for all schools. Our first drill will be a discovery procedure to better understand how the system works and what we might need to modify in the building to ensure that the procedure works efficiently.

If you have any questions, please email Barry Mansfield.

Grade 10 Theatre Arts students will be visiting the famous Trinity Laban Centre in Greenwich to see a dance theatre production of Company Wayne McGregor's Entity. The show has been described as 'awe-inspiring' and 'cutting edge'. The Times goes on to say:

“(Wayne McGregor's) keen embrace of science and technology, of pop and cyber culture, has made one of Britain’s top-­ranked choreographers” 

This show will help the Grade 10 Theatre Arts class in their study of Rudolf Laban's Movement Analysis, a technique that they will be applying in an original performance to an invited audience at the end of the school term. More details to follow shortly!

item.title: Halcyon Happenings: Newsletter 155
item.description:
Welcome to Halcyon's New E-newsletter!

We hope you like it as much as we do. There is a lot of news so if you have trouble viewing the entire e-newsletter please make sure to click "view entire message" at the bottom of the newsletter.

We would love to hear from you with any feedback, please email Eilidh MacIver.
Reminder School is Closed This Monday (03 October)
BIG NEWS! Read about Halcyon's fantastic first external exam results on our blog.
Community Day Trips, Tuesday 04 October
Learning at Halcyon has no boundaries and with London on our doorstep, we can stretch beyond the confines of the school to learn from the wonderful array of museums, tours, theatres, green and urban spaces that London has to offer. Being part of an international school community we appreciate that we have the opportunity to educate out students about the global community in which they live and study.

Our Community Days afford students the opportunity to learn more about London and the fundamental British values and diverse cultures that our capital classroom has to offer. We continue to deepen our awareness of a variety of British based institutions and their valuable contributions. 

Grade 6
Location: Education Centre at Hyde Park and the Natural History Museum
Students will visit the Education Centre at Hyde Park to complete a range of activities based on animal adaptations. They will then walk from Hyde Park to the Natural History Museum where students will explore various exhibits and review what they have studied so far in their Ecosystems unit by identifying different animals, the abiotic and biotic features of the ecosystems that they can be found in and their particular niches.

Students should bring their:
  • charged iPad 
  • topped up Oyster card
  • rain gear incase it rains
  • money for lunch or a packed lunch
  • filled water bottle
  • any spending money for the gift shop at the Natural History Museum (optional)
If you have any questions about the trip, please contact Kerry Jenkins.


Grade 7
Location: Vicente Cañada Blanch
This Spanish secondary school is managed by the Ministry of Education in Spain through the Spanish Embassy in London. Students follow the Spanish national curriculum from primary all the way through secondary. Halcyon’s Grade 7 students will experience a cultural exchange for one day discussing art, customs and history of Spanish speaking countries and sharing a tapas lunch with their Spanish peers. 

The aim of this trip is to further advance the harmony and understanding of different cultural traditions and practice their Spanish in an authentic way.

Students should bring their:
  • charged iPad 
  • topped up Oyster card
  • rain gear incase it rains
  • filled water bottle
If you have any questions please email Fatima Gonzalez.


Grade 8
Location: Science Museum
The visit to the Science Museum will consist of interactive exhibitions:
  • Who am I? Investigate some of the characteristics that make humans such a successful species, such as personality, intelligence and language
  • Engineering Your Future - discover what engineers do
  • Our Lives in Data - how big data is transforming the world
  • Workshop - construct your own vintage-style radio devices
These exhibitions link to the science and maths curricula (body systems / nutrition and digestion / electromagnetism / statistics).  

Students should bring their:
  • charged iPad
  • topped up Oyster card
  • comfortable walking shoes
  • money for lunch or a packed lunch
  • filled water bottle
If you have any questions please email Miguel Alcantud.


Grade 9
Location: East London and the Tate Modern
Grade 9 will be exploring East London on a street art tour and seeing how artists have expressed their social views at the Tate Modern. This will be a great opportunity to look at artistic expression, visual communication and contemporary graphics. The day will culminate in preparation for a debate that students will have in their Thursday PSHEE class. The debate will be entitled ‘The rule of law vs individual liberty' where students will discuss how law and liberty can both complement and contradict each other.

Students should bring their:
  • charged iPad 
  • topped up Oyster card
  • rain gear incase it rains
  • money for lunch or a packed lunch
  • filled water bottle
If you have any questions please email Gareth Jones.


Grade 10
Location: Tate Britain
Grade 10 will spend time exploring how British artists have expressed themselves through the use of the figure, and how this has been interpreted in both paintings and sculptures. This supports students in appreciating and understanding British Artists from 18 - 20th century. 

Art students will investigate how identity has been expressed through the body, making annotated notes on photographs of images using their iPads. They will further develop their understanding of the figure through observational drawings in their art books.

English students will use the figure as a starting point for creative writing, making connections to themselves and the British artists. They will then write a creative piece in response to one of the figurative art works.

Students should bring their:
  • charged iPad 
  • topped up Oyster card
  • rain gear incase it rains
  • money for lunch
  • filled water bottle
If you have any questions please email Sue Dance.


Grade 11
Location: Science Museum and Royal Courts of Justice
In the morning, students will visit the galleries relevant to their chosen science. For physics: space, Einstein's Legacy; for biology: Who am I; for chemistry: energy: Fuelling the Future / Challenge of Materials. 

In the afternoon we will visit the Royal Courts of Justice. Students will learn about the workings of the court and take part in a mock trial, based on Copyright law.

Students should bring their:
  • charged iPad 
  • topped up Oyster card
  • rain gear incase it rains
  • money for lunch or a packed lunch
  • filled water bottle
If you have any questions please email Stephanie Cooke.


Grade 12
Location: The Serpentine Galleries and The Saatchi Gallery
This trip will enable Grade 12 to connect to curatorial practice and decision making, which is a required element of the Visual Arts IBDP curriculum. 

The students will also use this opportunity to gain inspiration for ideas relating to their own studio work and concept development.

Students should bring their:
  • charged iPad

Halcyon Students Attend USA College Day 2016, Fulbright Fair on Saturday 24 September.
USA College Day offers students and parents the opportunity to meet with representatives from US universities in London, speak with educational service providers and attend a seminar about applying to US universities. In its 39th year, USA College Day is the largest American university fair in the UK and not to be missed by ay student considering undergraduate study in the US.

Last weekend a number of Halcyon Diploma Programme students attended the fair to speak with the 170+ exhibitors. Two of our Grade 11 students, Antonia and Ethan, spoke with us after the fair about their experience. 

Antonia: “The Fulbright Fair was amazing! There are five US universities that I am interested in and I got the chance to speak with each of them one-on-one. They offered me top tips on what research I should be doing on the universities before I apply and offered to meet and give me a tour when I go out to the US to do my university tour. One of the best aspects was that alumni members were present who gave a fantastic insight into life at the university. Overall I spoke to about 10-15 different universities and left the fair feeling excited about my next step in higher education.”

Ethan: “The fair gave me the opportunity to learn more about prospective universities and studying abroad in the US...it was awesome! I spoke to 15-20 universities. I went to the fair knowing that there were a couple I wanted to approach, there were some that I wanted to learn more about purely location wise, universities that I heard about but wanted to learn more and others that I stumbled upon. I would definitely recommend the fair to any student interested in studying in the US...it is a good opportunity to speak on a personal level with the representatives and ask lots of questions.”
Reminder: Lice Check
Last week we flagged a couple of reports of possible lice from parents. Please be aware that your child(ren) might have lice and not know it. So, how do you find out if they do?

Check their head when their hair is wet. Lice can only move very slowly when they are wet and therefore cannot hide. A thorough combing will remove the lice...however not their eggs.

How do I get rid of lice?
  • Wash hair with shampoo and rinse
  • Apply a thick conditioner and detangle with a wide toothed comb leaving the conditioner in the hair
  • Carefully comb through the hair with a special lice comb to remove all adult lice, moving from the base of the hair close to the scalp through to the hair end
  • Then while rinsing hair, comb through again with lice comb to remove any lice that have been dislodged
  • If lice are found, repeat the above steps on the following schedule: twice a week for the next two weeks. This should remove the lice that hatch from the eggs, which may have been laid
  • Remember to check at regular intervals to make sure that lice have not re-infected at some later date

''Tate Britain, sited on the old Millbank Penitentiary - a huge prison from where many men were deported to Australia - is now the home of British Art and, from these wonderful works, you can tell the history of this nation through its art. JMW Turner, has a whole wing to himself.'' 

Please sign up for this here. Contact Stacey Ciauri 07557520442 with any questions.

HPC: Take a Historical Tour Around Greenwich
Date: Wednesday 19 October
Time: 1000-1230
Cost: £15.00 per person to be paid on day of tour

Meet: at the Thames Clipper ticket booth opposite Embankment Tube Station at 1000 for a 1012 Clipper boat departure to Greenwich

Return: at the end of tour on the DLR
Halcyon parents are invited to come check out Greenwich with a professional elite tour guide and UK Historian Philippa Owen (she makes every tour worthwhile and fascinating).

Philippa says: "Greenwich, the gateway to London! A beautiful oasis on the mighty bend of the river, this World Heritage site looks over at Canary Wharf where once ships not banks traded their wares. Always a royal place, Henry the VIII and his two daughters were born there. The Queen's House and Mary II began the story of the Royal Naval College.Time is measured from there and its story is linked to the history of exploration and empire. A fascinating place, we will arrive by boat along the Royal River as so many have done before."

Please sign up here. Contact Stacey Ciauri 07557520442 with any questions.
HPC: Exhibition The Vulgar, Fashion Redefined
Location: Barbican Art Gallery
Date: Wednesday 23 November
Time: 1000-1200

Meeting Point: the Barbican (more details to follow upon confirmation)
 
Cost: £36 (including exhibition entrance ticket)
This new exhibition conceived by exhibition-maker Judith Clark and psychoanalyst Adam Phillip will look at the notion of vulgarity in fashion inviting the viewer to think again about exactly what makes something vulgar and why it is such a sensitive and contested term. Drawn from major public and private collections worldwide, the show will include contributions from leading modern and contemporary designers such as Walter van Beirendonck, Manolo Blahnik, Christian Dior, Marc Jacobs for Louis Vuitton, Stephen Jones, Christian Lacroix, Karl Lagerfeld for Chloé and Chanel, Alexander McQueen for Givenchy, Prada and Vivienne Westwood.

Please RSVP here. For any questions contact Stacey Ciauri 07557520442.

item.content:encoded:
Welcome to Halcyon's New E-newsletter!

We hope you like it as much as we do. There is a lot of news so if you have trouble viewing the entire e-newsletter please make sure to click "view entire message" at the bottom of the newsletter.

We would love to hear from you with any feedback, please email Eilidh MacIver.
Reminder School is Closed This Monday (03 October)
BIG NEWS! Read about Halcyon's fantastic first external exam results on our blog.
Community Day Trips, Tuesday 04 October
Learning at Halcyon has no boundaries and with London on our doorstep, we can stretch beyond the confines of the school to learn from the wonderful array of museums, tours, theatres, green and urban spaces that London has to offer. Being part of an international school community we appreciate that we have the opportunity to educate out students about the global community in which they live and study.

Our Community Days afford students the opportunity to learn more about London and the fundamental British values and diverse cultures that our capital classroom has to offer. We continue to deepen our awareness of a variety of British based institutions and their valuable contributions. 

Grade 6
Location: Education Centre at Hyde Park and the Natural History Museum
Students will visit the Education Centre at Hyde Park to complete a range of activities based on animal adaptations. They will then walk from Hyde Park to the Natural History Museum where students will explore various exhibits and review what they have studied so far in their Ecosystems unit by identifying different animals, the abiotic and biotic features of the ecosystems that they can be found in and their particular niches.

Students should bring their:
  • charged iPad 
  • topped up Oyster card
  • rain gear incase it rains
  • money for lunch or a packed lunch
  • filled water bottle
  • any spending money for the gift shop at the Natural History Museum (optional)
If you have any questions about the trip, please contact Kerry Jenkins.


Grade 7
Location: Vicente Cañada Blanch
This Spanish secondary school is managed by the Ministry of Education in Spain through the Spanish Embassy in London. Students follow the Spanish national curriculum from primary all the way through secondary. Halcyon’s Grade 7 students will experience a cultural exchange for one day discussing art, customs and history of Spanish speaking countries and sharing a tapas lunch with their Spanish peers. 

The aim of this trip is to further advance the harmony and understanding of different cultural traditions and practice their Spanish in an authentic way.

Students should bring their:
  • charged iPad 
  • topped up Oyster card
  • rain gear incase it rains
  • filled water bottle
If you have any questions please email Fatima Gonzalez.


Grade 8
Location: Science Museum
The visit to the Science Museum will consist of interactive exhibitions:
  • Who am I? Investigate some of the characteristics that make humans such a successful species, such as personality, intelligence and language
  • Engineering Your Future - discover what engineers do
  • Our Lives in Data - how big data is transforming the world
  • Workshop - construct your own vintage-style radio devices
These exhibitions link to the science and maths curricula (body systems / nutrition and digestion / electromagnetism / statistics).  

Students should bring their:
  • charged iPad
  • topped up Oyster card
  • comfortable walking shoes
  • money for lunch or a packed lunch
  • filled water bottle
If you have any questions please email Miguel Alcantud.


Grade 9
Location: East London and the Tate Modern
Grade 9 will be exploring East London on a street art tour and seeing how artists have expressed their social views at the Tate Modern. This will be a great opportunity to look at artistic expression, visual communication and contemporary graphics. The day will culminate in preparation for a debate that students will have in their Thursday PSHEE class. The debate will be entitled ‘The rule of law vs individual liberty' where students will discuss how law and liberty can both complement and contradict each other.

Students should bring their:
  • charged iPad 
  • topped up Oyster card
  • rain gear incase it rains
  • money for lunch or a packed lunch
  • filled water bottle
If you have any questions please email Gareth Jones.


Grade 10
Location: Tate Britain
Grade 10 will spend time exploring how British artists have expressed themselves through the use of the figure, and how this has been interpreted in both paintings and sculptures. This supports students in appreciating and understanding British Artists from 18 - 20th century. 

Art students will investigate how identity has been expressed through the body, making annotated notes on photographs of images using their iPads. They will further develop their understanding of the figure through observational drawings in their art books.

English students will use the figure as a starting point for creative writing, making connections to themselves and the British artists. They will then write a creative piece in response to one of the figurative art works.

Students should bring their:
  • charged iPad 
  • topped up Oyster card
  • rain gear incase it rains
  • money for lunch
  • filled water bottle
If you have any questions please email Sue Dance.


Grade 11
Location: Science Museum and Royal Courts of Justice
In the morning, students will visit the galleries relevant to their chosen science. For physics: space, Einstein's Legacy; for biology: Who am I; for chemistry: energy: Fuelling the Future / Challenge of Materials. 

In the afternoon we will visit the Royal Courts of Justice. Students will learn about the workings of the court and take part in a mock trial, based on Copyright law.

Students should bring their:
  • charged iPad 
  • topped up Oyster card
  • rain gear incase it rains
  • money for lunch or a packed lunch
  • filled water bottle
If you have any questions please email Stephanie Cooke.


Grade 12
Location: The Serpentine Galleries and The Saatchi Gallery
This trip will enable Grade 12 to connect to curatorial practice and decision making, which is a required element of the Visual Arts IBDP curriculum. 

The students will also use this opportunity to gain inspiration for ideas relating to their own studio work and concept development.

Students should bring their:
  • charged iPad 
  • topped up Oyster card
  • rain gear incase it rains
  • sketch book
  • money for lunch or a packed lunch
  • filled water bottle
If you have any questions please email Anthony Gow.
